questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents to the emergency department with a 1-day history of abdominal pain. The pain was initially periumbilical and has now localized to the right lower quadrant. There is associated anorexia and a low-grade fever. On examination, the child appears uncomfortable and has tenderness at McBurney's point. An ultrasound of the abdomen is ordered, suspecting appendicitis. What is the most common location of appendix?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Retrocecal

 

Option A:

 

At birth, the appendix is short and broad at its junction with the caecum, but differential growth of the caecum produces the typical tubular structure by about the age of 2 years (Condon). During childhood, continued growth of the caecum commonly rotates the appendix into a retrocaecal but intraperitoneal position.

 

The most common position of the appendix in both children and adults is the retrocecal location, where it lies behind the cecum. This anatomical variation occurs as the cecum grows and rotates during early childhood, pulling the appendix into this position.

 

Explanations:
 

Option B: Subcecal - The subcecal position is less common and occurs when the appendix is found beneath the cecum. This position can be associated with atypical presentations of appendicitis due to the altered anatomical location.

 

Option C: Pelvic - When the appendix lies in the pelvis, it is termed pelvic appendix. While it is a recognized position, it is not the most common location. Pelvic appendicitis can present with urinary symptoms due to irritation of the bladder.

 

Option D: Pre-ileal - A pre-ileal position of the appendix is relatively rare compared to the retrocecal position. It is placed in front of the terminal ileum and may also lead to atypical symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retrocecal position is the most common anatomical location of the appendix, resulting from the differential growth of the cecum and rotation during childhood.

 

Common locations: Retrocecal (74%) > Pelvic (21%)

 

 

Ref: 28th Bailey and Love, ed 1335

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with a history of right lower quadrant pain underwent an appendectomy. Histopathological examination of the surgical specimen revealed a tumor at the tip of the appendix. The most common neoplasm of the appendix is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Carcinoid

 

Option B:

 

  • The most common neoplasm primarily identified in the appendix are carcinoid tumors. They are detected in 0.3 to 0.9% of appendectomy specimens.
  • Carcinoids are the most common, accounting for approximately 66%, with cyst-adenocarcinoma accounting for 20% and adenocarcinoma accounting for 10% of the tumours of the appendix.

 

Carcinoid tumors are the most common neoplasms found in the appendix, accounting for approximately 66% of appendiceal tumors.

 

Explanations:


Option A: Adenocarcinoma - While adenocarcinomas can occur in the appendix, they are quite rare and account for only about 10% of appendiceal tumors.

 

Option C: Squamous cell carcinoma - Squamous cell carcinoma is extremely rare in the appendix and is not commonly found in appendectomy specimens.

 

Option D: Mucinous cystadenoma - Mucinous cystadenomas are a type of tumor found in the appendix, but they are not as common as carcinoid tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carcinoid tumors are the most common neoplasm found in the appendix, occurring in 0.3 to 0.9% of appendectomy specimens.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg 1349, Sabiston 21st Ed. Pg 1315.

choices.text: The common organisms implicated in appendicitis are anaerobic in nature
Luminal obstruction is the initiating event in acute appendicitis
Increased consumption of refined carbohydrates is implicated in acute appendicitis
Enterobius vermicularis, can proliferate in the appendix and occlude the lumen

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the etiology of acute appendicitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The common organism implicated in appendicitis are anaerobic in nature.

 

Option A:

 

While appendicitis is clearly associated with bacterial proliferation within the appendix, no single organism is responsible. A mixed growth of aerobic and anaerobic organisms is responsible.

 

Explanations:

 

Option B: Obstruction of the appendix lumen has been implicated as the initiating event and some form of luminal obstruction, either by a fecolith or by a stricture, is found in the majority of cases.

 

A fecolith (sometimes referred to as an appendicolith) is composed of inspissated faecal material, calcium phosphates, bacteria and epithelial debris, which leads to the buildup of mucus secretions and air due to bacteria. With progressive dilation, venous drainage may get hampered, leading to full-thickness ischemia and perforation.

 

Mechanism: Obstructed lumen of appendix → Retained secretions with distension of lumen → Secretions get infected → Venous occlusion due to increased pressure → Bacterial translocation → Gangrene & perforation → Appendicular abscess

 

Option C: Decreased dietary fiber and increased consumption of refined carbohydrates may be an important cause. In resource-poor countries that are adopting a more refined Western-type diet, the incidence continues to rise.

 

Option D: Intestinal parasites, particularly Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm), can proliferate in the appendix and occlude the lumen.

 

Educational objective:

 

The common organism implicated in appendicitis are a mixed growth of aerobic and anaerobic organisms.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th ed. Pg 1337.

questions.text: A 72-year-old male with a history of rheumatoid arthritis treated with methotrexate presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of progressively worsening abdominal pain, now localized to the right lower quadrant. He has a low-grade fever and mild leukocytosis. A CT scan of the abdomen suggests appendicitis without abscess or mass effect. All of the following are risk factors for perforation of appendix except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Retrocaecal appendix

 

Option B:

 

Pelvic appendix is a risk factor for perforation of appendix. Peritonitis occurs due to frank perforation of a gangrenous appendix.

 

The risk factors for the perforation of appendix include:

 

  • Immunosuppression
  • Extremes of age
  • Previous abdominal surgery
  • Pelvic position
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Fecolith obstruction

 

In such conditions, a rapidly deteriorating clinical course is accompanied by signs of diffuse peritonitis and systemic sepsis syndrome.

 

While a retrocecal appendix can make the diagnosis of appendicitis more challenging due to atypical presentation, it is not in itself a risk factor for perforation. The location of the appendix does not influence the risk of perforation as much as other factors do.

 

Explanations:

 

Option A: Fecolith obstruction - A fecolith can obstruct the appendiceal lumen, leading to increased intraluminal pressure, ischemia, and eventually perforation, thus it is a risk factor for appendiceal perforation.

 

Option C: Immunosuppression - Immunosuppressed patients, such as those on medications like methotrexate for rheumatoid arthritis, are at higher risk for perforation due to a potentially blunted immune response that can delay diagnosis and treatment.

 

Option D: Advanced age - Older patients are at a higher risk for perforation, possibly due to delayed presentation and diagnosis, as well as the presence of comorbid conditions that can complicate the course of appendicitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The retrocecal position of the appendix is not a risk factor for its perforation. Risk factors for perforation include fecolith obstruction, immunosuppression, extremes of age, previous abdominal surgery, a pelvic position of the appendix, diabetes mellitus, and others, but not the retrocecal position itself.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th ed. Pg 1338.

questions.text: Match the following signs seen in acute appendicitis with their named counterparts.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c

 

Option B:

 

Explanations:

 

Blumberg sign: Gentle superficial palpation of the abdomen, beginning in the left iliac fossa and moving anticlockwise to the right iliac fossa, will detect muscle guarding over the point of maximum tenderness, classically McBurney’s point. Asking the patient to cough or gentle percussion over the site of maximum tenderness will elicit rebound tenderness.

 

Rovsing’s sign: On pressing the left iliac fossa, pain is elicited in right iliac fossa

 

Psoas sign: Occasionally, an inflamed appendix lies on the psoas muscle, and the patient, often a young adult, will lie with the right hip flexed for pain relief (the psoas sign). On extension of the hip, he experiences pain in RIF.

 

Obturator sign: Spasm of the obturator internus is sometimes demonstrable when the hip is flexed and internally rotated. If an inflamed appendix is in contact with the obturator internus, this manoeuvre will cause pain in the hypogastrium (the obturator test; Zachary Cope).

 

Educational objective:

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg 1339

questions.text: A 10 years old girl is brought to the casualty with a history of abdominal pain and vomiting for the past 4 hours. On examination, the patient has pyrexia and there is tenderness and rebound tenderness in the right iliac fossa. Which among the following is the preferred imaging modality in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B.  Ultrasound of the abdomen

 

The clinical scenario is suggestive of acute appendicitis. In the pediatric population, ultrasound of the abdomen is the preferred imaging modality to identify the presence of an inflamed appendix.

 

It avoids the risk of radiation exposure. In adults, the best imaging modality is a CT scan. Modern CT is both sensitive and specific (approximately 95%) in the diagnosis of acute appendicitis and worldwide there has been a steady increase in its use for this purpose. CT has been shown to reduce the rate of negative appendicectomy

 

Reference: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1342

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a three-day history of right lower quadrant (RLQ) abdominal pain, fever, and nausea. A computed tomography (CT) scan reveals a 5 cm appendiceal mass without evidence of perforation or abscess formation, with adhered omentum (phlegmon). The patient's vital signs are stable, and he reports that the pain has not worsened over the past 24 hours. What is the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Conservative management

 

Explanation

 

If an appendix mass (phlegmon) is present and the patient's condition is satisfactory, the standard treatment is the conservative Ochsner-Sherren regime.

 

The Oshner-Sherren regimen includes:

 

  • Fasting (nil by mouth)

  • IV Fluids

  • Hot fomentation

  • Fowler’s position

  • IV antibiotics

  • Monitoring the size of lump

 

Criteria for stopping conservative treatment of an appendix mass

 

  • A rising pulse rate.

  • Increasing or spreading abdominal pain

  • Increasing size of the mass.

 

Educational objective:

 

Conservative management is considered in cases where an appendiceal mass/phlegmonous appendicitis is present, the patient's condition is stable, and there is no sign of complications, such as perforation or abscess.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg 1343

choices.text: Drain the collection without performing appendicectomy
Abandon the procedure and perform a proximal ileostomy

questions.text: 25 years old male presents with low grade fever and RIF tenderness. USG reveals dilated appendix with peri-appendiceal free fluid. On exploration via McArthur’s incision, an appendicular phlegmon is found. What will be the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Drain the collection without performing appendicectomy

 

Option B:

 

When an appendicular phlegmon is encountered, it's often safer to drain any abscesses and manage the patient with antibiotics rather than trying to remove the appendix, which may lead to bowel injury.

 

Explanations:

 

Option A: Complete the appendicectomy - Normally indicated for appendicitis, but if a phlegmon is present, attempting to remove the appendix may increase the risk of complications.

 

Option C: Limited right hemicolectomy - This procedure is more extensive and typically reserved for cases with a suspicion of malignancy.

 

Option D: Abandon the procedure and perform a proximal ileostomy - While this might be a safe option in some cases to avoid further complications, a proximal ileostomy is not indicated here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the presence of an appendicular phlegmon, it is safer to drain the collection and manage with antibiotics rather than performing an appendicectomy, which could increase the risk of bowel injury.

 

Special situations during appendicectomy:

 

  • The finding of a normal appendix demands careful exclusion of other possible diagnoses, particularly terminal ileitis, Meckel’s diverticulitis and tubal or ovarian causes in women. It is usual to remove the appendix to avoid future diagnostic difficulties, even though the appendix is macroscopically normal.

  • If an appendix mass is found at operation, particularly at laparoscopy, it may be safer to abandon the procedure rather than risk bowel injury during attempted mobilisation. Any abscess should be drained, intravenous antibiotics administered and the patient carefully monitored during the postoperative period. Very rarely in the face of a frankly necrotic appendix, a colectomy or partial right hemicolectomy is required.

  • Crohn's disease - If caecum is healthy- appendectomy

  • If cecum involved - avoid appendectomy

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1346

choices.text: It’s a persistent remnant of the Vitello-intestinal duct
It may contain heterotopic pancreatic mucosa

questions.text: Choose the incorrect statement concerning Meckel’s diverticulum.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is a false diverticulum.

 

Option B:

 

Meckel’s diverticulum is a true congenital diverticulum, containing all 3 layers of bowel, and has its own blood supply.

 

Meckel’s diverticulum is a true diverticulum, which means it contains all three layers of the bowel wall and has its own blood supply.

 

Explanations:

 

Option A: This is correct. Meckel’s diverticulum is indeed a remnant of the vitello-intestinal duct, which normally obliterates during embryonic development.

 

Option C: This is correct. Meckel’s diverticulum can contain heterotopic tissue, most commonly gastric and sometimes pancreatic.

 

Option D: This is correct. Meckel’s diverticulum can present with symptoms of diverticulitis, similar to those of appendicitis, or with bleeding due to ulceration caused by ectopic gastric mucosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meckel’s diverticulum is a true congenital diverticulum, which contains all layers of the intestinal wall and can present with complications like acquired diverticulitis.

 

  • It is a remnant of the Vitello-intestinal Duct, on the antimesenteric side of the ileum.

  • It is approx. 2 feet from the ileo-caecal valve and approx. 2 inches long

  • Sometimes, the mucosa of a Meckel’s diverticulum contains heterotopic epithelium of gastric, colonic or pancreatic type

  • Can present clinically as:

    • Hemorrhage in children due to ectopic gastric mucosa leading to ileal ulcers

    • Diverticulitis

    • Intussusception

    • Intestinal obstruction due to bands/volvulus- in adults

    • Perforation

    • Treatment: Meckel’s diverticulectomy/ileal resection and anastomosis

    • When found in the course of abdominal surgery, a Meckel's diverticulum can safely be left alone, provided it has a wide mouth and is not thickened. When there is doubt, it can be resected.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th ed. Pg. 1311- 1312

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with a significant history of bleeding per rectum and severe anemia. The diagnostic investigation reveals uptake in the area of the small intestine consistent with the presence of ectopic gastric tissue. What is the most appropriate treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Excision

 

Option D:

 

  • A 4-year-old presenting with severe anemia will most likely have bled from an ulcer adjacent to a Meckel’s diverticulum containing ectopic gastric mucosa. A 99mTc-pertechnetate scan may demonstrate ectopic gastric mucosa. The radionuclide is preferentially taken up by the mucus-secreting cells of the gastric mucosa and ectopic gastric tissue in the diverticulum.
  • Treatment of complicated Meckel's is diverticulectomy.

 

Excision of the diverticulum is the definitive treatment for bleeding caused by a Meckel's diverticulum, as it removes the ectopic gastric tissue that is likely causing the ulceration and bleeding.

 

Explanations:


Option A: While blood transfusion is important for addressing the acute anemia, it does not treat the underlying cause of the bleeding.

 

Option B: Endoscopic intervention may not be feasible in small children and may not provide a definitive treatment if a Meckel's diverticulum is the bleeding source.

 

Option C: Chemotherapy is not used in the treatment of Meckel's diverticulum.

 

Educational Objective –

 

To treat complicated Meckel's diverticulum with bleeding, excision of the diverticulum is the definitive treatment to remove the ectopic gastric mucosa and resolve the bleeding.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 261

choices.text: In congenital diverticulum, only the mucosa of the small bowel is present in the wall of the diverticula
Acquired diverticula often arise from the mesenteric side of the bowel
Bleeding is a very common complication
Ileum is the most commonly affected site for diverticular disease

questions.text: Choose the correct statement concerning intestinal diverticula.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acquired diverticula often arise from the mesenteric side of the bowel

 

Option B:

 

Acquired diverticula develop in the jejunum and arise from the mesenteric side of the bowel as a result of mucosal herniation at the point of entry of the blood vessels, where there is a potential defect in the muscularis layer.

 

Explanations:

 

Option A: In congenital diverticulum like Meckel’s diverticulum, all 3 coats of bowel are present in the wall of the diverticulum.

 

Option C: Bleeding from a jejunal diverticulum is a rare complication, compared with sigmoid diverticular disease.

 

Option D: Duodenum followed by jejunum are more commonly affected.

 

Educational objective: 

 

Acquired intestinal diverticula often develop in the jejunum, and arise from the mesenteric side of the bowel as a result of mucosal herniation at the point of entry of the blood vessels, where there is a potential defect in the muscularis layer.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1311

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with abdominal distension. Imaging reveals liver scalloping and omental caking. Intraoperative findings include multiple gelatinous deposits within the peritoneal cavity as shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pseudomyxoma peritonei

 

Option B:

 

Pseudomyxoma peritonei is characterized by the presence of mucinous deposits within the peritoneal cavity, often arising from a mucinous tumor of the appendix or ovary, matching the description provided.

 

Explanations:


Option A: Miliary TB usually presents with multiple granulomas throughout the body, including the peritoneum, but does not typically present with jelly-like cysts or scalloping of the liver.

 

Option C: Disseminated hydatid disease would show cystic structures caused by Echinococcus tapeworm infection, which usually has a different appearance on imaging and during surgery.

 

Option D: Gossypiboma refers to a retained surgical sponge or cloth after surgery, which can lead to a foreign body reaction but would not typically cause the extensive findings described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pseudomyxoma peritonei is diagnosed by the presence of jelly-like mucinous deposits in the peritoneal cavity typically originating from a ruptured mucinous tumor of the ovary or appendix.

 

Pseudomyxoma peritonei:

 

  • Usually seen in women
  • Peritoneal cavity studded with yellow jelly like cysts.
  • Believed to occur due to ruptured mucinous cystic tumour of ovary/appendix.
  • Patients typically present with progressive and massive abdominal distension, anorexia and symptoms of bowel dysfunction.
  • Rx: Complete cytoreduction (Sugar baker) = Multivisceral resection of right coIon, GB, spleen, greater and lesser omentum, peritoneal stripping.
  • HIPEC: Hyperthermic Intraoperative chemotherapy (Mitomycin C)

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1351-52.

choices.text: The base of the appendix is found at the confluence of the three taeniae coli of the caecum.
The appendicular artery is an end artery
Neuroendocrine tumors of the appendix arise from the mucosal cells present at the base of the crypts
There is usually abundant lymphoid tissue in the sub-mucosa

questions.text: Choose the incorrect statement concerning the anatomy of the appendix?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neuroendocrine tumors of the appendix arise from the mucosal cells present at the base of the crypts.

 

Option C:

 

Neuro endocrine tumours (NETS’s) arise from the argentaffin cells (Kulchitsky) which are situated at the base of the crypts, not mucosal cells.

 

Explanations:

 

Option A: The position of the base of the appendix is constant, being found at the confluence of the three taeniae coli of the caecum, which fuse to form the outer longitudinal muscle coat of the appendix.

 

Option B: Appendicular artery is an ‘end-artery’, thrombosis of which results in necrosis of the appendix.

 

Option D: The submucosa contains numerous lymphatic aggregations or follicles. The prominence of lymphatic tissue in the appendix of young adults seems to be important in the etiology of appendicitis.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

Neuro endocrine tumours (NETS’s) arise from the argentaffin cells (Kulchitsky cells) and not the mucosal cells which are situated at the base of the crypts.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed., Pg 1335, 1336

questions.text: A child with complaints of lower abdominal pain and nausea is being examined. On deep palpation in the left iliac fossa, the child experiences pain in the right iliac fossa as shown in the image. What is the name of this sign?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rovsing’s sign

 

Option C:

 

  • Deep palpation of the left iliac fossa may cause pain in the right iliac fossa, Rovsing’s sign, which helps support a clinical diagnosis of appendicitis.
  • The cardinal signs are those of an unwell patient with low-grade pyrexia, localised abdominal tenderness, muscle guarding and rebound tenderness.

 

This sign is positive when palpation of the left lower quadrant of the abdomen results in pain in the right lower quadrant. It suggests appendicitis and is the sign depicted in the image provided.

 

Explanations:
 

Option A: Blumberg sign - Also known as rebound tenderness, this sign is positive when pain is felt upon the quick release of deep pressure in the right iliac fossa. This is a general sign of peritoneal irritation, not specific to appendicitis.

 

Option B: McBurney's sign - This is tenderness at McBurney's point, which is located one-third the distance from the anterior superior iliac spine to the umbilicus. This sign is often used to localize pain in appendicitis.

 

Option D: Pointing sign - This implies the patient pointing towards the umbilicus as the site of initiation of pain, which later shifts to right iliac fossa.

 

Educational Objective:


Rovsing's sign is a clinical indicator in the diagnosis of acute appendicitis, characterized by pain in the right lower quadrant elicited by deep palpation of the left lower quadrant.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg 1339

questions.text: A 16-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a 10-hour history of abdominal pain that initially started around the umbilicus and has now localized to the right lower quadrant (RIF). The pain is associated with nausea and the patient reports loss of appetite. Physical examination reveals RIF tenderness and a low-grade fever. Laboratory tests show leukocytosis with a left shift. Which of the following parameters from the above-mentioned scoring system is given 2 points?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tenderness at RIF

 

Option C:

 

The most widely used is the Alvarado score A score of 7 or more is strongly predictive of acute appendicitis.

 

In patients with an equivocal score (5 or 6), abdominal ultrasonography or contrast-enhanced CT examination further reduces the rate of negative appendicectomy.

 

Tenderness in the right iliac fossa is a key clinical finding in acute appendicitis and is allocated two points in the Alvarado scoring system, which is a significant contribution to the diagnosis.

 

Explanations:

 

Option A: Anorexia - While anorexia is part of the Alvarado score, it contributes only one point to the total score.

 

Option B: Rebound tenderness - This finding is also included in the Alvarado score but is assigned only one point.

 

Option D: Nausea and vomiting - These symptoms are common in appendicitis, but in the Alvarado scoring system, they contribute only one point.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tenderness in RIF and leucocytosis are given 2 points in Alvarado score.

 

Alvarado score (MANTRELS)

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th ed, pg 1342

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 24-hour history of abdominal pain, initially periumbilical, now localized to the right lower quadrant. She reports nausea and has vomited twice. She also has a low-grade fever. On examination, there is tenderness and voluntary guarding in the right lower quadrant, but no rigidity. Her laboratory tests show a mild leukocytosis. Murphy’s triad of appendicitis includes the following clinical features except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Muscle guarding and rigidity

 

Explanation

 

Murphy’s triad in acute appendicitis includes:

 

  • Pain: Typically, peri umbilical pain which migrates to RIF

  • Vomiting due to severe pain

  • Fever typically, low grade

 

While muscle guarding may be present in acute appendicitis, rigidity suggests a more severe, generalized peritoneal irritation and is not typically included in Murphy's triad, which focuses on earlier, more specific signs.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The components of Murphy's triad in acute appendicitis: periumbilical pain that migrates to the right iliac fossa, vomiting, and low-grade fever. Muscle guarding and rigidity are associated with a more advanced stage of inflammation and are not part of the triad.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed., Pg. 1338-39

questions.text: A surgeon is preparing to perform an appendectomy on a 30-year-old patient with acute appendicitis. The surgical plan includes making an oblique muscle splitting incision in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen. What is the name of this incision?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gridiron incision

 

Option A:

 

Oblique muscle splitting incision in the right lower quadrant. Also called McArthur Incision. It is centred over the McBurney’s point.

 

This is an oblique muscle-splitting incision made in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen, often used for open appendectomy, also known as McArthur Incision. It aligns with the description provided.

 

Explanations:

 

Option B: Lanz incision - A Lanz incision is a transverse incision made approximately 2 cm below the umbilicus, centered on the midclavicular-mid inguinal line. It is not oblique but rather a transverse skin crease incision.

 

Option C: Rutherford-Morison incision - This is an oblique muscle-cutting incision, with its lower end over McBurney's point, extending obliquely upwards and laterally. It is more extensive and not typically used for a straightforward appendectomy.

 

Option D: Rocky-Davis incision - A Rocky-Davis incision is a transverse right lower quadrant incision. Although it is used for appendectomies, it does not match the oblique description given.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Gridiron incision is an oblique muscle-splitting incision in the right lower quadrant used for appendectomy.

 

  • Lanz incision:  Transverse or skin crease incision for appendicitis,2 cm below the umbilicus, centred on the midclavicular-mid inguinal line.

 

 

  • Rocky-Davis incision: Transverse right lower quadrant incision.

  • Rutherford-Morrison incision: oblique muscle cutting incision with its lower end over McBurney's point and extending obliquely upwards and laterally as necessary.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg 1344-45.

questions.text: A patient underwent an appendectomy for acute appendicitis. However, on the 6th day following surgery, the patient experienced spiking fever, abdominal pain, malaise and diarrhoea. Which post op complication is being described here?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intra-abdominal abscess

 

Option B:

 

Approximately 8% of patients following appendicectomy will develop a postoperative intra-abdominal abscess. In an era of hospital discharge 24–48 hours following appendicectomy, patients should be advised prior to discharge that a spiking fever, malaise and anorexia developing 5–7 days after operation is suggestive of an intraperitoneal collection and that urgent medical advice should be obtained.

 

Characteristically presents 5–7 days postoperatively with spiking fevers, abdominal pain, and generalized malaise, suggestive of an intraperitoneal collection, matching the clinical picture described.

 

Explanations:

 

Option A: Wound infection - Commonly presents with localized symptoms such as erythema, tenderness, and purulent discharge at the incision site, often occurring on the 4th or 5th day postoperatively, not typically associated with spiking fever or abdominal pain.

 

Option C: Portal pyemia - A rare complication involving infection of the portal venous system, typically presenting with multiple liver abscesses, jaundice, and systemic illness.

 

Option D: Fecal fistula - Presents with fecal drainage from the wound or the formation of a persistent sinus tract; this complication is less likely to cause spiking fever and would have distinct clinical signs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical presentation of a postoperative intra-abdominal abscess following appendectomy, includes delayed onset of spiking fever, abdominal pain, and malaise.

 

  • Abdominal ultrasonography and CT scanning greatly facilitate diagnosis and allow percutaneous drainage.

  • Surgical exploration should be considered in patients suspected of having intra-abdominal sepsis.

  • The most common complication however is wound infection typically occurring on the 4th or 5th day post op.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1347-1348

questions.text: CT signs of appendicitis include an appendix measuring greater than ______ in diameter?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 6 mm

 

Explanation

 

CT signs of appendicitis include an appendix measuring greater than 6mm in diameter and

 

  • Appendiceal dilatation (>6 mm outer diameter)
  • Wall thickening (>3 mm) and enhancement
  • Thickening of the caecal apex: Caecal bar sign, Arrowhead sign
  • Peri-appendiceal inflammation 
  • Focal wall non-enhancement representing necrosis (gangrenous appendicitis) and a precursor to perforation.

 

Educational objective:

 

CT signs of appendicitis include an appendix measuring greater than 6 mm in diameter.

 

Ref: Sabiston 21st Ed. Pg 1305

Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 1342.

Online source: https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-47125

choices.text: It's the most common extra uterine cause of acute abdomen in pregnancy
The cardinal feature of appendicitis in pregnancy is pain in the right lower quadrant
Conservative management by antibiotic should be tried
In cases of perforation, fetal mortality increases to 20%

questions.text: A pregnant patient at 24 weeks' gestation presents with acute onset right lower quadrant pain, nausea, and leukocytosis. Appendicitis is suspected. Choose the incorrect statement concerning appendicitis in pregnancy.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Conservative management by antibiotic should be tried

 

Option C:

 

While there are rare instances where conservative management might be considered, the standard of care for appendicitis in pregnancy is surgical intervention, not conservative management with antibiotics alone.

 

Explanations:

 

Option A: This is correct. Appendicitis is the most common extrauterine surgical emergency during pregnancy.

 

Option B: This is correct. The classic presentation of appendicitis, including right lower quadrant pain, remains the cardinal feature even in pregnancy, although the pain may shift as the uterus enlarges.

 

Option D: This is correct. The risk of fetal loss significantly increases in the presence of perforation, with mortality rates rising to 20% or more.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The standard of care for appendicitis in pregnancy is prompt surgical intervention, not conservative management with antibiotics.

 

  • It is the most common extrauterine acute abdominal condition in pregnancy. Appendicitis is slightly more common in the second trimester.              
  • Pain in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen remains the cardinal feature of appendicitis in pregnancy.
  • Delays in diagnosis or in the initiation of definitive treatment pose the greatest risk to the mother. Fetal loss occurs in 3-5% of cases of acute appendicitis in pregnancy but increases to 20% or more in the presence of perforation.
  • There is insufficient evidence to support a non-operative approach and the pregnant patient with acute appendicitis should proceed to surgery. If the fetus is at a viable gestational age (23 weeks or more), appropriate obstetric and neonatal support should ideally be available.

                                                           

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg 1346-47

choices.text: They are usually diagnosed during appendectomy for appendicitis
Most common type of appendicular neoplasm is a carcinoid
Size is the best predictor of malignant behaviour and metastatic potential
In tumours of size 1cm-2cm, negative margin appendicectomy is always done

questions.text: During the histopathological examination of an appendectomy specimen, a 1.5 cm tumor is identified at the base of the appendix. Which of the following statements regarding the management of appendicular neoplasms is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) In tumours of size 1cm-2cm, negative margin appendicectomy is always done

 

Option D:

 

The most common type of appendicular neoplasm is carcinoid, amounting to 60% of all appendiceal malignancies.

 

Explanations:

 

Option A: This is correct. Appendicular neoplasms are often diagnosed incidentally during appendectomy for presumed appendicitis.

 

Option C: This is correct. The size of the tumor is considered the best predictor of malignant potential and metastatic risk in appendicular neoplasms.

 

Option D: This is incorrect. For tumors between 1cm-2cm, a negative margin appendectomy is not always done. The decision is based on factors such as involvement of mesentery, lymph nodes, and the presence of clear margins. Right hemicolectomy may be considered if these risk factors are present.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neuroendocrine tumors are the most common type of appendicular neoplasms, and the management of these tumors is determined by the size, location, and presence of risk factors for malignancy.

 

  • NETs account for approximately 30-65% of appendix neoplasms while epithelial tumours account for most other cases. NETs arise in subepithelial neuroendocrine cells and the majority (70%) are located in the appendix tip.
  • The average age at presentation is 40-50 years and most patients are asymptomatic with early-stage disease typically found at appendectomy for acute appendicitis. Uncommonly, patients may present with symptoms due to a mass or metastatic disease. Carcinoid syndrome is extremely rare.
  • For tumors Up to 1 cm: Negative margin appendectomy done.
  • In tumors of size 1 cm-2 cm: Right colectomy is done if mesentery is involved, enlarged LN, ki67 positivity with positive or unclear margins. In the absence of above, appendicectomy suffices.
  • For tumors > 2 cm: Right hemicolectomy.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg 1349, Sabiston 21st Ed. Pg 1315.

questions.text: A patient with appendicitis was posted for an appendectomy procedure using the McBurney incision. Name the nerve most commonly injured with this incision.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Iliohypogastric

 

Option C:

 

The iliohypogastric nerve runs along a path that can cross the McBurney incision site, making it the most commonly injured nerve during this procedure.

 

Explanations:

 

Option A: The ilioinguinal nerve may be encountered in inguinal hernia repairs but is less likely to be injured in a McBurney incision for appendectomy.

 

Option B: The 11th thoracic nerve is not typically at risk during a McBurney incision, as this procedure is performed lower in the abdominal wall.

 

Option D: The subcostal nerve is higher in the abdominal wall and is not associated with a McBurney incision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The iliohypogastric nerve is the most commonly injured nerve during an appendectomy performed using a McBurney incision.

                                   

  • The gridiron incision (described first by McArthur) is made at right angles to a line joining the anterior superior iliac spine to the umbilicus, its centre being along the line at McBurney’s point.
  • If better access is required, it is possible to convert the gridiron to a Rutherford Morison incision (see below) by cutting the internal oblique and transverse muscles in the line of the incision. The iliohypogastric nerve is most commonly injured.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg. 1344

questions.text: Meckel's diverticula in the inguinal hernia sac is called as?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Littre's hernia

 

Option D:

 

Meckel's diverticulum can be found in inguinal or femoral hernia sacs is known as Littre's hernia and can cause intestinal obstruction.

 

Explanations:

 

Option A: Amyand's hernia is characterized by the presence of a normal or inflamed appendix within an inguinal hernia sac.

 

Option C: Richter’s hernia involves the herniation of only one sidewall of the bowel, which may lead to strangulation without causing intestinal obstruction.

 

Option D: Littre's hernia involves the presence of Meckel's diverticulum within an inguinal hernia sac and can potentially lead to complications such as intestinal obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Littre's hernia is the term for a hernia containing Meckel's diverticulum, which may present with complications like intestinal obstruction.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 1060.

choices.text: In children, it presents with features mimicking acute appendicitis
It commonly arises from the ileum
Tc99m scan is used to demonstrate bleeding Meckel’s
Incidentally found Meckel’s can be left alone if it is broad based.

questions.text: Which of these is incorrect about Meckel’s diverticulum?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) In children, it presents with features mimicking acute appendicitis

 

Option A:

 

If gastric mucosa is present from birth, peptic ulceration can occur and present as painless dark rectal bleeding or melaena in children. This is the common presentation for Meckel’s diverticulum.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: This is correct. It is found on the antimesenteric side of the ileum approximately 60 cm from the ileo-caecal valve and is classically 5 cm long (2% prevalence; 2 feet [60 cm] from ileo-caecal valve.

 

Option C: If the stomach, duodenum and colon are excluded as a source of bleeding by endoscopy, radioisotope scanning with technetium-99m may demonstrate a Meckel’s diverticulum.

 

Option D: If a Meckel’s diverticulum is found incidentally at surgery, it can be left provided it has a wide mouth and is not thickened.

 

Educational objective:

 

Meckel’s diverticulum in 20% cases contains ectopic gastric mucosa which may lead to ileal ulceration and painless PR bleed in children.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg 1311-12.
